trans-unit.source: Title: Build and Deploy your ASP.NET 5 Application to an Azure Web App ms.TocTitle: Deploy ASP.NET 5 to Azure Description: Build and Deploy your ASP.NET 5 Application to an Azure Web App toc: show ms.ContentId: B5F1C4D4-6A3D-48A0-9D88-3E1B7BF5D152
trans-unit.target: Title: Build and Deploy your ASP.NET 5 Application to an Azure Web App ms.TocTitle: Deploy ASP.NET 5 to Azure Description: Build and Deploy your ASP.NET 5 Application to an Azure Web App toc: show ms.ContentId: B5F1C4D4-6A3D-48A0-9D88-3E1B7BF5D152

trans-unit.source: Build and Deploy your ASP.NET 5 Application to an Azure Web App
trans-unit.target: Build and Deploy your ASP.NET 5 Application to an Azure Web App

trans-unit.source: You can build and deploy your ASP.NET 5 app from Visual Studio Online or your on-premises Team Foundation Server.
trans-unit.target: You can build and deploy your ASP.NET 5 app from Visual Studio Online or your on-premises Team Foundation Server.

trans-unit.source: Note: ASP.NET 5 and DNX (the .NET Execution Environment) is a lean .NET stack for building modern cloud and web apps.
trans-unit.target: Note: ASP.NET 5 and DNX (the .NET Execution Environment) is a lean .NET stack for building modern cloud and web apps.

trans-unit.source: To learn more visit the <linkText>aspnet Home project</linkText><title></title> on GitHub.
trans-unit.target: To learn more visit the <linkText>aspnet Home project</linkText><title></title> on GitHub.

trans-unit.source: Getting Started
trans-unit.target: Getting Started

trans-unit.source: Push your code to a Git repository in your team project.
trans-unit.target: Push your code to a Git repository in your team project.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have code but you want to try this out, you can download some sample code <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have code but you want to try this out, you can download some sample code <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Note: if you are using the sample project you can skip the following steps.
trans-unit.target: Note: if you are using the sample project you can skip the following steps.

trans-unit.source: Create a file called Prebuild.ps1 in the folder that contains the global.json
trans-unit.target: Create a file called Prebuild.ps1 in the folder that contains the global.json

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Prebuild.ps1</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Prebuild.ps1</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Open it in your favorite editor and add the following code
trans-unit.target: Open it in your favorite editor and add the following code

trans-unit.source: Create a Scripts folder in your repository and add a file called PublishAspNet5Website.ps1.
trans-unit.target: Create a Scripts folder in your repository and add a file called PublishAspNet5Website.ps1.

trans-unit.source: Open the file in your favorite editor and add the following code.
trans-unit.target: Open the file in your favorite editor and add the following code.

trans-unit.source: Commit and push these changes.
trans-unit.target: Commit and push these changes.

trans-unit.source: Register your Azure subscription
trans-unit.target: Register your Azure subscription

trans-unit.source: Before you can setup a definition to deploy your application you need to add your Azure Subscription to your team project collection.
trans-unit.target: Before you can setup a definition to deploy your application you need to add your Azure Subscription to your team project collection.

trans-unit.source: You will only need to do this once per subscription.
trans-unit.target: You will only need to do this once per subscription.

trans-unit.source: Go to your project page (https://{youraccount}.visualstudio.com/DefaultCollection/{yourteamproject}) and click on the small gear in the upper right corner.
trans-unit.target: Go to your project page (https://{youraccount}.visualstudio.com/DefaultCollection/{yourteamproject}) and click on the small gear in the upper right corner.

trans-unit.source: Select the Services tab and click Add new Azure Subscription link on the top left.
trans-unit.target: Select the Services tab and click Add new Azure Subscription link on the top left.

trans-unit.source: Click on Add new Azure Subscription in the top left and fill in your subscription details.
trans-unit.target: Click on Add new Azure Subscription in the top left and fill in your subscription details.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Subscription Dialog</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Subscription Dialog</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To get your subscription file:
trans-unit.target: To get your subscription file:

trans-unit.source: Open a Microsoft Azure PowerShell window
trans-unit.target: Open a Microsoft Azure PowerShell window

trans-unit.source: Type Get-AzurePublishSettingsFile
trans-unit.target: Type Get-AzurePublishSettingsFile

trans-unit.source: This will open a browser and automatically download your subscription file.
trans-unit.target: This will open a browser and automatically download your subscription file.

trans-unit.source: Open the subscription file named SubscriptiionName.Date-credentials.publishsettings
trans-unit.target: Open the subscription file named SubscriptiionName.Date-credentials.publishsettings

trans-unit.source: Location the SubscriptionId and ManagementCertificate elements
trans-unit.target: Location the SubscriptionId and ManagementCertificate elements

trans-unit.source: Create the definition
trans-unit.target: Create the definition

trans-unit.source: Go to your project page (https://{youraccount}.visualstudio.com/DefaultCollection/{yourteamproject}) and click on the Build.Preview hub.
trans-unit.target: Go to your project page (https://{youraccount}.visualstudio.com/DefaultCollection/{yourteamproject}) and click on the Build.Preview hub.

trans-unit.source: Click on the green plus sign and select Visual Studio from the Definition Templates dialog and click ok.
trans-unit.target: Click on the green plus sign and select Visual Studio from the Definition Templates dialog and click ok.

trans-unit.source: For now remove the Visual Studio Test and Index Sources steps.
trans-unit.target: For now remove the Visual Studio Test and Index Sources steps.

trans-unit.source: Click on the Repository tab and make sure the repository containing your application is selected.
trans-unit.target: Click on the Repository tab and make sure the repository containing your application is selected.

trans-unit.source: By default a new definition selected the repository with the same name as the team project.
trans-unit.target: By default a new definition selected the repository with the same name as the team project.

trans-unit.source: Add a PowerShell build step and drag and drop to the top of the list.
trans-unit.target: Add a PowerShell build step and drag and drop to the top of the list.

trans-unit.source: In the Script filename: input browse to the PreBuild.ps1 script.
trans-unit.target: In the Script filename: input browse to the PreBuild.ps1 script.

trans-unit.source: Select it and click OK.
trans-unit.target: Select it and click OK.

trans-unit.source: Select the Visual Studio Build step and in the Solution input browse to the .xproj.
trans-unit.target: Select the Visual Studio Build step and in the Solution input browse to the .xproj.

trans-unit.source: Select it and click OK.
trans-unit.target: Select it and click OK.

trans-unit.source: In the MSBuild Arguments input add the following properties.
trans-unit.target: In the MSBuild Arguments input add the following properties.

trans-unit.source: /t:Build,FileSystemPublish /p:PublishConfiguration=$(BuildConfiguration) /p:PublishOutputPathNoTrailingSlash=$(Build.SourcesDirectory)\{yourProjectName}\artifacts\bin\$(BuildConfiguration)\Publish
trans-unit.target: /t:Build,FileSystemPublish /p:PublishConfiguration=$(BuildConfiguration) /p:PublishOutputPathNoTrailingSlash=$(Build.SourcesDirectory)\{yourProjectName}\artifacts\bin\$(BuildConfiguration)\Publish

trans-unit.source: Note: $(Build.SourcesDirectory) is one of a number of variables you can use in your build definition, you can learn more here
trans-unit.target: Note: $(Build.SourcesDirectory) is one of a number of variables you can use in your build definition, you can learn more here

trans-unit.source: Add an Azure PowerShell step and drage and drop it above the Publish Build Artifacts step.
trans-unit.target: Add an Azure PowerShell step and drage and drop it above the Publish Build Artifacts step.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Subscription input select the subscription you regsitered above.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Subscription input select the subscription you regsitered above.

trans-unit.source: In the Script Path input browse to the PublishAspNet5Website.ps1 script in your repository.
trans-unit.target: In the Script Path input browse to the PublishAspNet5Website.ps1 script in your repository.

trans-unit.source: In the Script Arguments input add the following parameters.
trans-unit.target: In the Script Arguments input add the following parameters.

trans-unit.source: -websiteName {yourWebsiteName} -packOutput $(Build.SourcesDirectory)\{yourProjectName}\artifacts\bin\$(BuildConfiguration)\Publish
trans-unit.target: -websiteName {yourWebsiteName} -packOutput $(Build.SourcesDirectory)\{yourProjectName}\artifacts\bin\$(BuildConfiguration)\Publish

trans-unit.source: Note: -websiteName should be the name of a Web App you have created in your Azure Subscription referenced above.
trans-unit.target: Note: -websiteName should be the name of a Web App you have created in your Azure Subscription referenced above.

trans-unit.source: Save your definition
trans-unit.target: Save your definition

trans-unit.source: Click Queue build... and click OK in the dialog.
trans-unit.target: Click Queue build... and click OK in the dialog.
